div.p: 1. V. Central Market— Cloudy.

Heard Mr Presbury at Mr Little’s from Job 14.14. “If a man die, shall he live again.” This is a young man, graduated at Brown University, Providence, and has been some time a theological student at Cambridge— His subject was a future State, or the immortality of the Soul; and his argument that it was not discoverable by the light of Nature; and that the only assurance of it upon which we can rely is in the gospel of Christ— There were pathetic and eloquent passages in the discourse, and the argument from natural reason against continuous existence after death was urged with force and candour— It was presented in its most painful aspect; the eternal separation from those whom we have cherished upon Earth— After exhausting the topic of natural reason, and quoting several passages from the Old Testament, shewing that the doctrine of eternal life was not there; he made a sudden transition to the doctrine of the Gospel, by repeating without preliminary remark the words of Jesus—“Lazarus, come forth”—which he followed up with remarks, upon the restoration to life of Lazarus, and the subsequent resurrection of Jesus himself, in proof of the belief in a future State— Mr Little after the service, administered the Communion, in which I joined— Dr. Thornton whom I had met in the street, accompanied me to Church, but came away before the Communion service was over— Between the Morning and afternoon Service, Mr Pleasonton called to visit me and said he was going tomorrow on a tour of a fortnight to Lancaster County, Pennsylvania— I spoke to him of the movements in the House of Representatives on the subject of my old Accounts; and read to him the draught of the Letter I had written jointly to him and to the Comptroller Anderson— I asked him also for the volumes containing the Accounts of Ministers abroad; heretofore settled; which he promised to send me tomorrow Morning— In the afternoon I heard Mr Baker, from Micah 6:6— [“]Wherewith shall I come before the Lord, and bow myself before the high God? shall I come before him with burnt offerings with calves of a year old? 7. Will the Lord be pleased with thousands of Rams, or with ten thousands of Rivers of Oil? shall I give my first born for my transgression, the fruit of my body, for the sin of my Soul? 8. He hath shewed thee, O man, what is good; and what doth the Lord require of thee, but to do justly, and to love mercy, and to walk humbly with thy God?”— This most admirable text contains in itself a whole system of ethics—it includes all the duties of man towards his fellow creatures and towards God— No Sermon can do Justice to it— In the Evening I heard Mr Presbury again—from Psalm 34:8. “O taste and see that the Lord is good”—the discourse though sensible was less impressive than that of the morning. I wrote to Governor Lincoln of Massachusetts.
2. IV:15. symbolsRound Capitol Square Sun symbols

Mr Southard called twice in the course of the Morning first to mention letters received from Commodore Hull in the Pacific, and from Rodgers at Malta, in December; and afterwards to read to me a reply from General Jackson, to the answer Southard had sent him to the Letter which Jackson had written to him about the after dinner Conversation last Summer at Fredericksburg— The reply is in two or three sheets of paper; written in a coarse and insulting Style, somewhat verbose, and with passion partly suppressed; alledging that he had received the statement of Mr Southard’s remarks from Dr Wallace and a Mr Johnson, in writing—these were two of the guests at table— He complains that Mr Southards answer is argumentative, instead of plain matter of fact; which he had expected; and then it enter into large historical details to shew that he received no proper supplies from the War Department for
the defence of New-Orleans, but saved that City by obtaining pistol flints from Barataria— He finishes the Letter by announcing it as a close of the Correspondence— Borosky was a stranger who announced himself as a Polish Officer wanting money to go to Philadelphia, where he expected to obtain relief from S. Girard— The impositions I have endured from pretenders of this description have made me callous to their applications— I denied him; not without reluctance— Colbert is a Chickasaw Indian Youth, about 17. who has been living two years for education with Coll. M’Kenney, and being now on the point of departure to return home, came to take leave. Coll. Roberdeau, brought me a note from W. Elliot, mentioning the hours of eclipses of Jupiter’s Satellites, for some weeks to come: among which was one at ten O’Clock this Evening— Coll. Roberdeau mentioned also a plan that he has formed for improving the Militia; upon which he is preparing a paper— Mr Ironside came and introduced Coll of Delaware; a stranger; but who immediately commenced upon politicks— Says Delaware is broken all to pieces, and knows not who will be elected to the House of Representatives, in the place of L. M’Lane—perhaps W. H. Welles. Mr Burges of Rhode-Island called—detained here by the illness of two of his daughters— Spoke of a Marine Hospital, which the Delegation from Rhode-Island have requested might be erected at Providence— Expressed some doubts as to the right of Congress to levy a tax of 20 Cents a Month upon the wages of Seamen; but without recurring to that he thought it just that the money should be expended where it had been raised— I told him I had heard that point much discussed heretofore in Congress, and the argument used that the Seamen of New-England were much oftener sick at the Southern Ports than at home— He will see me again upon this subject before he leaves the City— Evening very heavy— Catarrh still troublesome.
3. IV:10— Round Capitol Square— Sun rose veiled.

Mr Rush called with a draft of a Letter to the Attorney General, requesting him to attend in behalf of the Government, at the Circuit Court to sit next week at Philadelphia, upon the trial of the cases, which have arisen from the frauds of Edward Thomson, upon the Custom-House at that place. He had also a Letter to C. J. Ingersoll the District Attorney, to be taken by Mr Wirt; and I recommended that a Letter should be written immediately written to Mr Ingersoll, giving him notice now that Mr Wirt would come on to assist him in the management of those Causes— Governor Barbour brought Letters received from J. Crowell, Agent to the Creek Nation, and from Lieutt. Vinton from which appears that it will be very difficult to prevail upon the Indians to cede the Lands in dispute and claimed by Georgia— General Macomb called for a visit with Lieutenant Monroe who comes from Point Comfort— The General afterwards sent me a specific remedy for a cough, to be taken by the teaspoonful Night and Morning— I suppose an opiate— Mr Betton called for his papers which I gave him— Cabinet Meeting at one—all present—the drafts of Letters to Generals Scott and Gaines were discussed and amended, softening the expressions in many passages. The general order to be issued to the army was also considered— That such an order should be issued was thought advisable by all— The terms of the draft were considerably modified— After this was disposed of Mr Clay read his draft of a Letter of Instruction to Mr Gallatin: containing a reply to Mr Canning’s last Note on the Colonial Trade— He apologized for its length; and also for the more than moderation of its tone— It answers and refutes all that has a shew of reason in Canning’s note; and points out its departures from matters of fact. It proceeds to state our assent to the principle of regulating the trade by Legislation— Then states what we are inclined to offer by Law; and instructs Mr Gallatin to enquire, first whether they will in consequence of our opening the trade to their vessels, without discriminating duties, and yielding to them the circuitous voyage, open the Ports to our vessels
Secondly, if they will not open them upon those terms, whether they will upon others, and what terms— Mr Rush had already seen this draft, and Mr Clay wished that Governor Barbour, before he leaves the City, and Mr Southard should examine it— Southard said he thought there was rather too much of concession in it. I inclined to the same opinion myself. Evening solitary, and incapable of labour.
4. IV. Round Capitol Square— Sun rose veiled.

Mr Rush called twice in the course of the morning; first with two or three Letters from Norfolk, asking further relief from the effect of the proclamation; one being the case of a British Vessel from Jamaica in distress, and for which permission is asked not only to unlade and sell her Cargo, but to take one in return. The other was a question whether Spain, sent as a remittance to a house in this Country, could not be admitted— Mr Rush’s opinion was that neither of these applications could be indulged, and I concurred with him— The second call was to read to me two or three Letters from C. J. Ingersoll— One asking that the Captains of two Revenue Cutters, which boarded E. Thompson’s Tea Ships should be ordered to attend as Witnesses, at the U.S. Circuit Court, to sit next week at Philadelphia— Another mentioned confidentially as advices received from China that two of the persons who are bondsmen for the present Collector at Philadelphia, W. Jones, were doing bad business, by which their credit may be affected. Mr Hubbard, announced himself as a Presbyterian Clergyman, engaged at an Academy in the County of Baltimore. He had a companion with him; but their object in coming was apparently nothing more than curiosity— Mr Driscoll is a Master of a Vessel, and came to ask me to order the discontinuance of a suit, against him pending in the U.S. Circuit Court at Baltimore; in the name of Andrew Armstrong, Commercial Agent at Port-au-Prince Hayti, for not delivering to him his Ship’s Register— He had a long Story of complaint against Armstrong— I told him that the suit being in Mr Armstrong’s name, I had no authority to order the discontinuance of it— He then presented me a written complaint against Armstrong signed by himself and three or four more Masters of Vessels, on a charge of his having taken of them excessive fees— I told him, Mr Armstrong, upon his return home, which was shortly expected would be apprized of this complaint, and called to answer it— Wilson came to enquire if I had seen the District Attorney, Mr Swann, upon his business: I had not; and he said that Swann was now absent at Alexandria— Governor Barbour called to take leave. He is going to-morrow on a visit to his Estate in Virginia. He had a Letter from John H. Pleasants interceding for Fayette Norvell, one of the Cadets under sentence at West-Point for the Christmas frolic— I asked him if he proposed to take no further measure, for the purchase of the Creek-Indian Lands; or upon the complaint by the Little Prince and other Chiefs against Crowell— He thought nothing further would be necessary till after his return, which he intends in three or four weeks— Mr Frye was here this Evening, and said he would call again to confer with me, about the Lands claimable by Mr Johnson’s heirs— About Mr Donaldson, and Ringgold— Mary Hellen dined abroad at Mrs Pleasonton’s— I made a Later Evening than the last—labouring to seek in assiduous occupation a truce from troubled thoughts, the most oppressive of which regard my Son George.— I signed 25. Blank Military Land-grants of the late war— The Peach trees in our Garden appeared first this morning in their blushing honours. I am slowly recovering from the Catarrh.
5. IV. Round Capital Square— Cloudy— Rain

Rush— Richard— The only visitor of this day was Mr Rush, who came to take directions for the final arrangement with Mr Wirt, the Attorney General, to attend the U.S. Circuit Court at Philadelphia, upon the trials of Indictments, and of several Suits arising from the frauds of Edward Thomson— Mr Rush is likewise engaged in drawing a Lottery of Certificates of 6. per Cent Stocks to be paid off on the first of July— There was a warm rain, continued nearly through the day—and which visibly advanced the vegetation— Of the young trees set out round the public buildings, the Tulip is next to the willow putting forth its leaves— The Sycamore shews nothing yet but swollen buds— I received a Letter from my Son George of the 31st. he had as I apprehended been for five or six days prevented from writing by illness— I read part of the Court-Martial proceedings on the Cadets at West-Point: and employed the Evening industriously in writing.
6. IV. Round Capitol Square— Cloudy— Warm— No fire

Mr Southard came for a final decision, what should be done upon the report of the Court of enquiry, on the complaints against Lieutt. Coll. Smith of the Marine Corps. Mr Southard had sent me the draught of a Letter to the Coll. severely censuring him upon various points exhibited by the Report, but finally letting him off from a Court-Martial, on the ground that there was contradictory testimony, and that some excuse was found in the ill health with which he has been for some time afflicted— It finished by ordering him to duty. I observed to Mr Southard, that the conclusion seemed not to harmonize with the body of the Letter, and although the Report of the Court of enquiry authenticates the complaint of Mrs Little that there were unsettled Accounts between her and Coll. Smith, yet this Letter would leave her without remedy and release him from the obligation even of settling the Accounts— I thought it would be more advisable to write to Coll. Smith that before any decision here upon the Report of the Court of Enquiry, it was expected that he should settle his Account with Mrs Little, to her satisfaction or by judgment of Law—with the resolution if he makes this settlement, to leave without farther notice the remaining charges— There was also a Letter from Captain Kuhn, paymaster of the Marine Corps, complaining that Coll. Henderson had deprived him of the service of his Clerk, by an arbitrary order, which he makes the subject of an additional charge against the Coll. I advised Mr Southard to write forthwith an order to Coll. Henderson, to forbear all interruption of the paymaster in the paymaster’s duties—and to keep any subsequent measure for further consideration— Mr Frye called and shewed me the Letters of Mr Donaldson and Mr Ringgold which he had mentioned to me. Ringgold, asks for 350 dollars, to enable him to commence a suit for 4000 Acres of the Land— Donaldson declines furnishing his quote of the contribution, and declines also purchasing the right of the heirs of Mr Johnson— All I thought could thereon be done, was to enquire if he would sell his portion of the right, as representing the heirs of Wallace and Muir— Mr Frye took also the papers relating to the House that was Easters, on a claim of Corcoran to a lien, by virtue of a Deed of Trust given by Easter before he had any title—about which they have drawn me into chancery— Mr Frye took the papers to consult them previous to giving the deposition for which he expects to be called— Mr John Barney, the member of the House of Representatives from Baltimore, called to pay a visit— He comes here to see his Son who is at the Columbian College, and who has written him, that the establishment was likely to be broken up and dissolved— Dr Staughton the President having resigned— Barney spoke of the disposition of the people of Baltimore as being very favourable, which is a flattering view of the Subject— There is at least more zeal in the opposition. They have held a very large Meeting there adopted slanderous Resolutions against the Administration—appointed a numerous Committee of Correspondence, and fixed some day in May for another Meeting at which their compeers throughout the State are to be represented— The same course is pursuing in every
quarter of the Union— Mr Noland is an applicant for an appointment of a Clerk in any one of the Departments— He comes from Rockville and applied two years ago— Mr Clay came to request I would examine his Letter of Instruction to Mr Gallatin, which he wishes to despatch as soon as possible— He read me two flattering Letters from Harrisburg— Mr Elgar came for my approbation of Mr Bulfinch’s plan of a jail at Alexandria, which I accordingly subscribed— Mrs W. S— Smith dined with us— Judge Cranch called in the Evening, and returned the two Volumes he had borrowed the Massachusetts State Papers and Novanglus.
7. V: Round Tyber Square. Sun rose 5:38

On reading this morning Mr Clay’s draught of Instruction to Mr Gallatin, upon the Colonial trade question, I found myself drawn to the consideration of it, with a view to the examination of it more historically than I have yet done— I read again Mr Rufus King’s Speech, upon the passage of the first of our Navigation Acts in 1818. and found some Acts of Parliament having a bearing upon the subject as early as 1805. I began to collect the Documents, for a laborious task, and even this absorbed nearly the whole Morning— Antoine was occupied in pasting my name and engraved arms in many of my books. Dr Watkins called upon me, with a Letter from D. Trimble, asking for a copy of my Letter to the Legislature of Massachusetts in June 1808. resigning my Seat in the Senate of the U.S. which he says he wants to use in his Stump Speeches. He says too that his opponent abuses me, for some vote that he pretends I gave against extending the right of suffrage; and enquires what it means.— I examined the Journals of the Senate; and found in January 1808. the Bill for extending the right of suffrage in the Mississippi Territory— But I voted for this Bill, and against an amendment less favouring the popular right of suffrage, which prevailed at the time; although the principle for which the amendment was substituted has since been established by a Law in 1814. Trimble’s opponent must speak upon some false Statement or misrepresentation of my votes— I gave Watkins a copy of my Letter of resignation. Mr Tippett wrote me a Letter—soliciting the appointment of Superintendent of the Penitentiary, and then asked to see me, he remained half an hour descanting upon his admirable qualifications for the place, to which I told him that no appointment would be made for the present— There is no time so ill employed as that of listening to the self-eulogium, and importunities of these Solicitors for petty-Offices, when there are none to bestow— Their eagerness to obtain a promise, and their propensity to construe every kind word into one, makes it necessary to be reserved in conversing with them, and this becomes in their estimation, chilling frigidity— After dinner I walked round the garden Square with Mrs Adams
8: III:45. Morning Garden walk— Sun rose cloud-veiled.

The day was as fine as could pass over the head of mortal man— Cloudless from a quarter of an hour after Sun rise— Temperate and Spring like— The process of vegetation was manifested upon many trees— They put forth their Leaves in the following order—Weeping Willow—Lombardy Poplar, Horse Chesnut, Tulip-tree: Sycamore—Locust— The first of which are now full dressed in the verdure of Spring— This day brought forth the first shew of the Locust leaf— I could not discover a trace of the Nuts, or Acorns that I planted last November— I heard Mr Little, from Psalm 75.3. “The earth and all the inhabitants thereof are dissolved: I bear up the pillars of it. Selah. 4. I said unto the fools, Deal not foolishly: and to the wicked, Lift not up the horn: 5. Lift not up your horn on high: speak not with a stiff neck.” This was a desultory discourse; half written, half extemporaneous, and without much point— Mr Baker in the afternoon gave a direct exposition of his tenets, from Luke 13.24. [“]Strive to enter in at the strait gate: for many I say unto you, will seek to enter in, and shall not be able.” In the Evening, with Johnson Hellen, I heard Mr Little again from Romans 6:21. “What fruit had ye then, in those things whereof ye are now ashamed? for the end of those things is death”— Not more impressive than this Morning. I wrote to George.
9. V. Round Capitol Square— Rain.

In my morning walk round the Capitol Square, I noticed the putting forth of the leaves of some of the trees— It is already late in the Season for such observations— They should have been commenced in February; with the shooting of the willow— I have marked the order in which the trees falling under my observation, put out their leaves— The variety in their manner of vegetating is so remarkable, that I am humiliated by the heedlessness with which I have suffered this process, to pass at least fifty times before my eyes, without bestowing a thought upon it— There was a moderate rain this day; which will give a spur to vegetation— Mr Southard called to mention two Letters he had received from Mr Robbins the Senator, and Mr D. J. Pearce the member of the House from Rhode-Island—the former urging the appointment of a Mr Cranston, as Navy-Agent in that State; the Latter recommending that no appointment should be made at present— I thought this most advisable— Mr Southard also left with me sundry papers from Coll. Henderson, relating to the complaints of Captain Kuhn against him— General Wool paid me a morning visit. Just at the close of the last Session of Congress, he received a Brevet Commission as Brigadier General; for ten years service, with the rank of Colonel: and his object now was to claim pay according to his brevet rank; because it is allowed to General Macomb, the Chief Engineer— Wool claims it, as Inspector-General; and assigns the arduous nature, and value of his services, and the expenses incidental to the performance of them as the grounds of his claim— I referred him to the War Department, where the decision upon it must be made— I had some leisure this day; which was chiefly absorbed by a Volume supplementary to Anderson’s History of Commerce; containing Statements of the proceedings of the British Government concerning our intercourse with their Colonies after the Peace of 1782. information for which I was upon the lookout.
10. V: Round Capitol Square— Cloudy.

Observing the process of vegetation upon the trees, the developement of the leaves continues. Those of the Maples are at their first appearance of a rusty reddish colour; some of them are this day first assuming verdure— The clusters of Lilac-blossoms in the garden are formed; and begin this day to open— Mr Tyler called on me with a remnant of engraved Prints of my father and myself which he wished me to take off his hands— But the Prints are, both very indifferent, and I declined taking them. Mr Tyler solicited also some appointment having been unfortunate in his business; and lost much as an endorser. Mr Rush introduced Dr Mease, just arrived from Philadelphia— He has been employed by Mr Rush, to prepare a full Memoir upon the cultivation of Silk, and the Silkworm: and has come to examine the books and documents on the subject already collected under the Resolution of the House of Representatives— Mr Rush had also Letters, from Norfolk, Virginia and from Portland, Maine, concerning the interdiction of British Vessels from the Colonies an importation of Specie at Norfolk—and of Jamaica Rum, from Halifax at Portland. These are forfeitures to be remitted— Mr Rush afterwards called to enquire if part of the compensation to Dr Mease for the work he has undertaken might be now paid him; to which I assented— Mr D. Brent was here— The Books for the Department of State, which Mr Gallatin had been requested to procure have arrived— I asked for one of them but it appeared to have been sent to the Book-binder— Edward Wyer was here; just returned from a visit to Mr Monroe at Oak-hill— Says Mr Monroe labours personally upon his farm, and mentioned much of his Conversation, and that of Mrs Monroe—of Mr and Mrs Hay and of Hortensia. Dr Lovell came with his phrenological instrument, and took the measure of my head, in its proportions— There is a phrenological Society here, in correspondence with one at Edinburgh in Scotland— The Scotch Society have sent a Golgotha of their great men, to the Society here, requesting a return of the like Commodity— The Society here have therefore taken the measure of twenty-heads to send as Samples to Scotland, one of which was mine— Chief Justice Marshall, Messrs.Calhoun, Clay, Barbour, Rush, Southard, Wirt, M’Lean, Woodbury, Tazewell, M’Duffie, Mitchell of Tennessee, Cheves, Webster, Berrien, and judge Johnson are of the numbers.
11. V: Round Capitol Square— Cloudy.

I still notice in my early morning walk, the different processes of nature in unfolding the foliage of different trees and plants; but without being able to describe them— Observation to be useful should be confined to one or to a very few objects at a time—to particulars from which some inference may be drawn, to operate upon practice—and should be perseveringly continued— There came this morning a person from Georgetown, who introduced three others from Frederick. Waggoners going to Alexandria, and down the River to purchase fish—Shad and Herring for catching which now is the Season— They came to see me, as did Mr Scribner from Illinois— He had the model of a machine which he has invented, and for which he proposed to take out a Patent— He discoursed Politics, and avowed himself a friend of Governor Edwards and of Mr D. P. Cook. I sent for Foy who is setting out trees here, and who found all the English Acorns that I received from Mr Coleman of Salem dead— He said also that none of the Nuts which I planted last Autumn, even if they succeed will come up before June— Borland the Carpenter came also for directions which I gave him to make me a Book-case— A Subject about which it is expedient to reflect with a general consideration of the safest, and most convenient mode of keeping Books and papers for ages, and from generation to generation— I gave him the dimensions of one Book-case, to be made experimentally; and upon the trial of which I shall order a second and third— These are preparations for an Office and Library which I propose to build for my retirement at Quincy— Mr Triplett came to enquire for my decision upon his appeal from the cashiering Sentence of a Court-Martial, which I have approved. He had a few days since obtained a recommendation signed by several respectable persons at Alexandria, that he might be appointed Collector of some port in Florida— He asked me if I had received it. I said I had— That it was painful to me to tell him my impressions concerning him, but that candour required it of me. The Sentence of the Court Martial had declared him addicted to habitual intemperance— I could not appoint a man to any civil office, dismissed from the military service for that cause— He said he came to ask me to suspend my opinion for two or three Months within which time he hoped to be able to furnish unequivocal proof, that injustice had been done him by that Sentence— I agreed to this— Mr Brent mentioned that the French Minister the Baron de Mareuil, about to go away upon a leave of absence, wished an Audience to take leave; for which I fixed Monday at One O’Clock— Mr Forrest brought for signature an Exequatur for a Sardinian Consul, but it was incorrectly made out and he took it again to the Department. Mr Bulfinch called with Mr Stafford from Boston, an inventor of warming Stoves, whom he proposes to employ at the Capitol— The Lehigh Coal and the Philadelphia grates have rendered improvements for warming this house unnecessary. Mr Coles late Governor of the State of Illinois called on his return from a long visit to Philadelphia and New-York— With Mr Clay I had a final conversation upon the Instructions to be given to Mr Gallatin, relating to the question of the British Colonial trade. He said he had adopted all my suggestions minuted on the draught of his despatch, excepting an objection to the closing paragraph, which I thought too direct a threat of hostility; and which he finally promised to soften— He also proposed to leave it discretionary with Mr Gallatin whether to make any overtures for particular reciprocal Legislation or not. My Inclination was against it. We had also some conversation upon the expediency of confining henceforth Appointments to our friends—about which I was averse to giving any public pledge—a point upon which I am much importuned— Mr G. W. P. Custis paid me an Evening visit— There was a party at Mr. Southard’s attended by my Sons and Mary Hellen— Mrs Adams unwell—
12. IV.15. George 26.— Round Capitol Square. Cloudy.

Mrs Mayhew is the wife of a man who was in prison for the costs of a prosecution against him for stabbing one with whom he had a quarrel. She came with a petition for his discharge— She asked to see me—said nothing in behalf of her husband; but brought a child of about two years old in her arms— The man had already suffered the term of imprisonment ordered by the Sentence of the Court. I gave an order for his discharge. Mr Graham came for directions concerning the Execution of two Acts of Congress of the last Session, one containing a cession of Land to the State of Ohio, for laying out a certain Road—and the other for ascertaining the Northern Boundary of the State of Indiana— And also respecting the resale of relinquished Lands in the State of Alabama. There was a Letter from the Commissioner for locating the road, according to which I desired that the Lands bordering on the road as projected on a plat among the papers should be reserved from Sale on both sides— The Surveyor General is to be directed to see to the Execution of the Act for ascertaining the Northern Boundary of Indiana, in concert with the Governor of that State, to whom Mr Graham will also write— We had a recent Letter from W. R. King, the Senator from Alabama, requesting an early decision upon the resale of the relinquished Lands in Alabama— I directed that they should not be sold before the Meeting of Congress; according to the earnest request of all the members of that delegation— Mr Nourse, the Chief Clerk of the War Department came to mention a new difficulty at West-Point—between Coll. Thayer the Superintendent, and Captain Hitchcock and Lieutt. Gird, which he thought would render it necessary to remove the two latter of these Officers from that Station— The papers have been sent on to Governor Barbour. I asked Nourse some questions respecting the character of Captain Hitchcock; which he said stood perfectly fair, both for veracity and Spirit— I requested also a copy of an order from the War Department of August 1826. referred to in a Letter from Coll. Thayer, and which Major Nourse afterwards sent me. Philip Hopkins is from Stanton, Virginia, a visitor for curiosity— Mr M’Lean the Postmaster General introduced Dr Drake: a very distinguished Physician of Cincinnati Ohio— He is travelling Eastward, to visit a Son whom he has at School, at or near Boston. Mr Burges spoke again of the application for a marine hospital at Providence, and brought a statement shewing that since 1802 there had been near 10000 dollars more collected from the Seaman’s tax in Rhode-Island, than expended— I desired him to see and converse with the Secretary of the Treasury; and promised a speedy decision. William Elliot junr brought me a Letter from his father— He is going to London to study Architecture, and wished some introductory Letter from me to assist him— I promised him one to Leslie. Dr Watkins introduced Dr M Cauley of Baltimore. Mr Rush came to mention the result of Dr Mease’s visit— He was with him all day yesterday, and departed this morning on his return to Philadelphia; with many of the documents and Books collected respecting silk and the silkworm— I spoke again to Mr Rush, respecting the project of procuring seeds and plants from foreign Countries which may be usefully naturalized in this Country— There was a Letter from Mr Crawford to our Consuls abroad on this subject, but which has produced no result; because it authorised no expence— We discussed this matter at some length, and must return to it again— I thought we might venture upon some small expense, to collect certain specific seeds or plants, and have them planted in the garden of the Columbian Institute— We had company to dine— Genl. and Mrs Wool, Mrs and Miss Pleasonton, Mary Roberdeau, Mr and Mrs Frye; Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith. Dr. Huntt and Edward Wyer— Johnson Hellen dined out— I received a Letter from George, and wrote to him.
13. V:30. Just at Sunrise— Walk to the bathing rock—

I have already been tempted by the prevailing warm weather to bathe in the Potowmack, but have been deterred by the Catarrh, still hanging upon me, and by the warnings of physicians, whose doctrines are not in harmony with my experience— I took however for this morning’s walk, the direction to the River, and visited the rock whence I most frequently go into the River— It is yet adapted to the purpose; but all trace of the old Sycamore tree which was near it, and blew down the winter before last, is gone. There is yet one standing a little below; but it is undermined with every high tide; and must be soon overthrown. The borders of the river are strewed with dead herring and shad: and the waters are not so high as usual at this Season— The French Minister the Baron de Mareuil came at one O’Clock, and was introduced by Mr Clay— He is going upon a tour to the interior of New-York, perhaps into Canada, and thence to Boston—intending to return to embark the first of July at New-York for Havre. He said he was going upon a leave of absence, not knowing whether he should return here or be otherwise disposed of. I assured him of my good wishes, and that it would give us pleasure to see him here again. And I desired him to assure his Government of the continued earnest desire entertained by us to be upon the terms of harmony with France. He spoke in equal terms of courtesy, and expressed himself grateful for the treatment he had received in this Country— These were words of course, and without much cordiality, or more sincerity than there is in the closing Salutation of a Letter— Mr Clay mentioned a despatch of 26. February received from Mr Gallatin— The remainder of the day was without interruption— Borland the Carpenter came to say that he had been obliged to go to Alexandria to procure St. Domingo Mahogany— That he would want 200 feet for my two Book cases—and must give 25 dollars a hundred for the wood— He is to make the two Cases accordingly— I continued the reading of the proceedings of the Court-martials on the Christmas frolic at West Point—wrote two short Letters and began a draught of an Article upon the Colonial Trade question with Great-Britain— My health continues drooping— Mary Roberdeau remained here last Night and this day.
14. IV. Round Capitol Square— Sun rose 5:29.

Mr Southard has been upon a short visit to Baltimore. He came to ask for directions concerning the feuds which have arisen between Coll. Henderson Commandant, and Captain Kuhn, Paymaster of the Marine Corps— They have all sprung from tattling and tale-bearing, and I asked if it was not possible to give the parties privately to understand, that a trial of such things by a Court-martial would be discreditable to them all— He said he would make an effort to reconcile them without official interference, and if that should prove unsuccessful he proposed to call a Court of Enquiry with directions to report the facts and their opinion upon them— Mr Ringgold has just returned from a visit to Mr Monroe at Oak-Hill; and brought me, as Wyer had done, a message of friendly sympathy from him— Mr Minnis and his wife with another man and two Ladies whose names were not announced are travellers from Hartford and Stafford in Connecticut, who came to Washington, to see the President’s House and the President, and other curiosities of the Metropolis— They sent a special request to be permitted to see me with which I readily complied— Dr Caldwell comes from Lexington Kentucky, and is proceeding Northward— Dr Holley has resigned his Office as President of the Transylvania University, and is going to Europe to superintend a School of boys, from this Country
to be educated there under his tuition— Caldwell says he has about ten boys who are going with him, and expects as many more— But Caldwell thinks it a wild and absurd project which must fail. The principle of educating American boys in Europe, is bad, but Dr Holley’s device for defraying the expense of travelling and residing some time in Europe himself is ingenious enough. He has a restless ambition, not suited to his profession— If his undertaking fails, it will be chiefly from this cause— Dr M’Cauley is engaged upon the newly projected Rail road from Baltimore to the Ohio river; for the Surveys of which he wishes to have assistance from the Engineers of the United States: this project has entirely superseded that of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal; and a subscription of several Millions of Dollars has been filled at Baltimore for effecting it— They have however not yet ascertained that it will be practicable; and the great object of the work is to secure a large portion of the internal trade from the Western Country to the City of Baltimore. I told Dr M’Cauley, that whatever assistance could be given by the Engineers of the United States should be willingly yielded— Mr Forrest brought again for signature the Exequatur of Cazenove as Sardinian Vice-Consul at Boston— Coll. Roberdeau to speak of his Memoir upon the organization of the Militia— Mr Brent, to enquire if the outfit of H. Wheaton as Charge d’Affaires to Denmark might now be paid to him, at his request, though he proposes not to embark till July—I said it might be paid, Mr Wheaton being notified that his Salary will commence only from the time of his departure upon his Mission— Mr Rush brought some documents relating to the Condition of the Marine hospital fund; and thought it doubtful whether the application of Mr Burges and the Rhode-Island delegation for the erection of a hospital at Providence could be complied with— It appears that for the last seven years the balance of the expenditures over the receipts from that fund in Rhode-Island is rather against the State— But in the period from 1802. it is near 10,000 dollars on the other side. On full consideration I thought half that sum, might be applied to the Hospital at Providence, and that the balance between the Receipts and Expenditures might be fully restored by a further appropriation hereafter— Mr Clay mentioned that Mr John Speed Smith had declined accepting the appointment of Secretary to the Mission to Tacubaya; but there is no necessity for an immediate appointment to supply his place— I was industriously occupied in the Evening.
15. V:— Cloudy.

Heard Mr Little, from Luke 11.44. “Woe unto you, Scribes and Pharisees, Hypocrites! for ye are as graves which appear not, and the men that walk over them, are not aware of them. 45. Then answered one of the lawyers, and said unto him, Master, thus saying thou reproachest us also. 46. and he said, Woe unto you also, ye lawyers! for ye lade men with burdens grievous to be borne, and ye yourselves touch not the burdens with one of your fingers.”— This discourse appeared to be an apology for delivering in the pulpit sentiments, at which individuals take offence as though intended to be applied personally to them. It is difficult to animadvert upon any vice or immorality without bearing upon those who are addicted to them—and yet the pulpit is not the place for reproving individual transgression; at least in the present age—and the preacher justly observed that it is often Conscience that holds the Mirror, and makes the offender apply to himself that which was mere general observation, made without any intention of reference to him— Mr Baker’s afternoon discourse was from Matthew 5.4. [“]Blessed are they that mourn: for they shall be comforted.” There is never anything very impressive in the substance of Mr Baker’s Sermons— There is great and ardent devotion in his manner, and he has a certain fluency: never wanting words; though often repeating the same— His power is not proportioned to his Zeal— A great clatter of copper coins will not make them pass for gold— In the Evening I heard again Mr Little from Colossians 1.5. “For the hope which is laid up for you in heaven, whereof ye heard before in the word of the truth of the gospel; 6. Which is come unto you as it is in all the world; and bringeth forth fruit”— The fruit of the gospel is the hope laid up in Heaven— Wrote to George. The weather continues warm— Apple trees in blossom— Lombardy Poplar, Horse Chesnut, Tulip-tree, in full leaf— Sycamore, Maples, Locusts, unfolding— Catalpa leaves first shooting— Lilacs open. Strawberries in blossom—
16. IV:30. Round Capitol Square— Cloudy.

Mr Pleasonton returned two days since from his tour to Lancaster County Pennsylvania— Alexander Scott came again to solicit an appointment. He also shewed me a Letter from Mr M’Culloch, Collector at Baltimore stating that there were two kinds of Inspectors of the Customs: one permanent, and the other occasional— That the former received pay all the year round, 3 dollars a day; and the latter only for the days upon which they were in actual service— He said he had Letters from several other Collectors to the same effect— His Son had sometime since claimed pay as Inspector at Pensacola, for about two years, while he was living here at Georgetown; upon the ground that he was here to clear his character from charges against him proferred by the Collector of Pensacola, who has himself since been removed from his office for misconduct. Mr Rush had decided against this claim of young Scott: the Law expressly providing that Inspectors shall be paid only for the time when they are actually employed— I confirmed this decision of Mr Rush; which Mr Scott acknowledges to be conformable to the Law, but urges the practice to be otherwise— The Baron de Mareuil, with his Lady, and two daughters came to pay a parting visit to Mrs Adams. Coll. Bomford brought plans of the Penitentiary now building, and of the Arsenal adjoining upon it— There is some question between him, and the Commissioner of Public Buildings Elgar concerning the division of the Land at the Point applied to these two Public purposes. Asbury Dickins called to see me being just convalescent from a confinement of two or three Months with a rhumatic fever.— William Elliot junr came and took the Letter of introduction, which I had written for him to Mr Leslie the Painter at London. I am yet able to occupy the Evening in writing; and am still signing Blank Land-grants.
17. IV:45. Round Tyber Square— Sun rose 5:24.

Mr Graham called to enquire concerning the Settlement of the Accounts of Silas Dinsmoor, which he proposed should be referred to the present deputy Surveyor Turner, to which I agreed— He also requested my signature to an order on the back of a diagram, of certain Lands covered with Cedar in the state of Alabama— They were surveyed by Hutton and Cathcart in 1819. and it was then recommended that they should be reserved from Sale, to keep for the use of the Public the very fine timber growing upon them— But they had already been sold— The greater portion of them have now been relinquished to the United States, and the Secretary of the Navy has requested that they may be reserved from resale until it can be ascertained, whether they have been stripp’d of their Cedars or not— It was an order to this effect, which Mr. Graham had sent me to be signed in February; and which I now signed and gave him— Mr Southard came and observed that all prospect of reconciliation between Coll. Henderson and Captain Kuhn of the Marine Corps, was hopeless, and he proposed that a Court of Inquiry should be convened, to report the facts and their opinion, upon the charges exhibited by Kuhn against Henderson— After canvassing the names of the Officers to be selected for this service, he concluded to take Brevet Lieutt. Coll. Gamble, and two Captains for the Court of Enquiry— So that there may remain two brevetted Lieutt. Colonels of the Corps who may be ordered to serve on the Court-Martial, if it should be necessary to call one. Mr Stonestreet and Mr Holland are inhabitants of Rockville, and called as visitors with Johnson Hellen.
Mr Cutts came to enquire if I had examined the papers he some time since left with me, concerning the claims of General D. Parker, and General Gibson, for arrearages of double rations— I had not read the papers, and asked him to leave them a few days longer with me— But in the mean time told him I should certainly not interfere in the case— Mr Forrest came for a document which he thought he had left here, but I could not find it— The Commission of the Sardinian Vice-Consul for whom an Exequatur was issued— William Lee intimated to me, that Mr Varnum, Member of the House from Massachusetts, was a little hurt, at not having been sufficiently noticed by me. He sometime since married the widow of his cousin, who had resided here, and is yet in the City— I told Lee that it must be the Lady, who thought herself not sufficiently noticed; and I would bear it in mind— Lee is compiling a book, on the culture of the grape, and making wine. Mr Rush spoke of a Letter from Mr Wirt the Attorney-General, at Philadelphia, concerning the cases there pending of E Thomson’s frauds upon the Custom-house— The six hundred Indictments which Ingersoll had brought forward in the Circuit Court have all been dismissed by the advice of Mr Wirt, since a judgment of the Supreme Court here, in favour of the Lippincotts; and Mr Wirt has a fearful misgiving that all the other cases preceding will turn out not more favourably to the Public— He has sent an agent to procure testimony at New-York, which Mr Rush proposes to approve, and he recommends a prosecution in the State Court, for a conspiracy to cheat—which I apprehend would also fail of success— I was much harassed this day with interruptions but spent the Evening in writing.
18. IV. Round Capitol Square. 1. hour. Sun rose 5:23. behind S.E. Chimney State Department.

Mr Southard was here twice—first to deliver me a Letter, enclosed to him from T. Newton Late member of the House of Representatives from Norfolk— It mentions the death of Mr Pryor, the Collector of that District, and requests me not to make an appointment immediately— Newton’s service in Congress began with the Century, and he has been twenty-six years, without interval a member of the House. He is now again a Candidate and his election is sharply contested, as is that of every other friend of the Administration that was in the last Congress from Virginia— All the bitterest adversaries to us, will be returned again without opposition— Bussard came with a petition for indulgence upon a debt which he owed to the Bank of Columbia at Georgetown, and which has by them been transferred to the United States or the Bank of the United States— It is secured by a mortgage of real Estate, and his petition is that the Sales of this may be suspended, and that he may be enabled by contracts for delivering gunpowder, to pay the debt— I referred him to the War and Navy Departments, and to the fifth Auditor— Mr Gatewood from Norfolk, came to apply for the Office of Collector, vacated by the death of Mr Pryor. He represented himself as peculiarly well qualified for it, and assured me, that if the appointment were to be made by the people of the place, he should be certain of obtaining it— He said he had not thought it necessary to procure recommendations, but could get as many as he could desire— I told him the appointment would not be immediately made— Mr Bradley is from Connecticut, and also an applicant for an Office; of which I have none to bestow upon him— Mr Rush read me the draught of a Letter which he has written in answer to that of Mr Wirt; approving his having sent to New-York for Testimony upon the Thomson Tea-Cases, and also his advice to commence in the State Court of Pennsylvania, a prosecution for a conspiracy to cheat—upon which he says that the conviction of the parties, would be certain—but of this I greatly doubt. Mr Rush made also some enquiries, concerning the University at Cambridge, in contemplation of sending one or two of his Sons there: the Columbian College here, where he had placed them being in a state of dissolution— The President, Doctor Staughton has resigned, and the whole establishment is on the eve of breaking up; demolished by its debts— I gave Mr Rush some general information concerning the course of Studies, and the expenses at Cambridge, and lent him two pamphlets containing all that he could be desirous of knowing on the subject— Dr Todsen came and stated to me that there was now a person here by the name of Humphreys, who would bear testimony to the personal hostility to him, which actuated the Officers on the Court-Martial, by whom he was tried—but this person would be here only a few hours— I said
he should draw up a statement of what he should testify, in writing, and make oath to it before a magistrate— He, Todsen might then send it to me, and I should put it on file. Todsen again repeated his application for an appointment; and said he was endeavouring to get into professional practice; but hitherto without success— Mr Southard’s second call, related to a Seaman, named Joseph Morris, who deserted last July from a British Packet at New-York, and afterwards entered in one of our Public Ships, under the name of Montgomery— A Letter from Lord Melville, of the British Admiralty to Mr Gallatin mentioned the facts, and stated that the Captain of the Packet charged the Deserter with having carried off with him from 3 to 400 dollars— Upon examination of the man by Commodore Chauncey, he admitted that his name was Morris and that he left the British Packet, last July, but denied having taken the money. We concluded to discharge the man, and to give such notice to the British Consul, that he may prosecute him in the judicial Courts for stealing the money if he thinks proper— Mr Clay had Letters from Mr Hammond at Albany, and some others— My evening task was too much abridged—
19. IV:5. Round Capitol Square— Cloudy.

Nairn came to solicit the appointment of Messenger to the Commission for the distribution of the Slave-indemnities, which is to assemble here on the first of July. He is a Stone-cutter; but wants this office, being too much out of health to work at his trade— I told him he must wait until the Commission should meet; and then apply at the Department of State— Mr Southard came with Letters from a Lieutenant Cunningham, who upon being ordered on a particular duty, asks a furlough for a year or as the alternative tenders his resignation— I advised that the resignation should be simply accepted. He had also a Letter from Lieutt. Stockton, engaged in a Survey of Southern Harbours: Savannah Charleston and Beaufort—wishing to be relieved, before the coming on of the dangerous heats. His request is to be complied with. The Lexington Sloop of War having returned from her cruize in the West-Indies, is to be ordered to the Mediterranean— And the Cyane, expected home within two Months will be ordered to the Coast of Labrador— Mr Southard had a Richmond Enquirer, in which was an Editorial Article, alluding to his dinner conversation at Fredericksburg, and charging it as an attack from Head Quarters, upon General Jackson’s character— Southard asked if I thought it necessary for him to notice it. I thought not.— Coll. Bomford came to enquire if I had decided the question about the road between the Arsenal and the Penitentiary— I had not seen Mr Elgar concerning it, but promised to send for him, and to give Bomford his Answer shortly. He spoke also of the Court Martial Trials for the Christmas Riot among the Cadets at West-Point— His Son was one of the Offenders; and was sentenced to be dismissed, with the privilege of resigning— He asked if I had decided upon the trials— I had not, being unwilling to determine one case, until I should have read through all the proceedings, which I have now done— I told him I should decide upon them all in a few days— He spoke with a sore feeling of the difficulty which has arisen, concerning the appointment by Coll. Thayer of a Court of Enquiry and of the Sentence of the Court-Martial upon Cadet Berrien, disqualifying him for Service in the army of the United States forever— He complained also that there was no proper graduation of punishments at that Institution— There is much delicacy in this affair, in which whatever decision I make will be sharply censured. Lee came with two papers, to which a Conversation between him and the Minister from the Netherlands, Bangeman Huygens gave rise— This Minister had heard that in the original laying out of this City there were lots reserved and assigned for all foreign Ministers, whose Governments might be disposed to build upon them Houses for their Residence— Lee wrote to enquire of the Commissioner of the Public Buildings, how was the fact, and now brought Elgar’s answer, with a copy of a circular Letter written in 1798. by the Commissioners of the City, to the foreign Ministers then residing in the City and offering to each a lot, for their use to build upon, if they should think proper. It appeared from Elgar’s Letter that the Minister of Portugal only, accepted the offer, and that there is a lot upon
the President’s Square, still reserved as belonging to the Government of Portugal; but no house has been built upon it, and there is now no Minister from Portugal residing here— I told Mr Lee, that if Mr Huygens was desirous of building, I presumed that a lot might still be assigned to the Government of the Netherlands, under the original offer; and he said he would give the papers and refer the Minister to the Secretary of State— Johnson Hellen, and my Sons John and Charles, dined with Dr. Watkins.
20. V:30— Garden walk—and round the House Square.

Mr Graham brought me a Synopsis of the public Lands within the present boundaries of the States and Territories to the first of January 1826. from which it appears that the Quantity of Land purchased by the United States exceeds 258 Millions of Acres, of which near 139 millions have been surveyed, and upwards of 19 Millions sold, for about 40 millions of dollars—more than 32 Millions of which have been paid— There have been upwards of 7 Millions of Acres, reserved for Schools, and the quantity remaining unsold exceeds 210 Millions— The sums paid for public Lands have been little short of thirty-three Millions of Dollars, exceeding by about half a Million the proceeds of the Sales; but this includes the whole purchase money for Louisiana and Florida; all the sums paid to the State of Georgia, for Lands, and all the expenses of surveying and of Sale— The Lands remaining within the limits of the United States, North and West of the boundaries of the States and Territories are estimated at 750 Millions of Acres— It appears also that the amount of duties received at the Custom-House at New-Orleans to the 30th. of September last is more than 15 1/2 Millions— This Statement is well suited to shew the immense value of the Lands to the Union; but will not suffice to preserve them from the Rapine of some of the Western Spirits— I gave Mr Graham a Letter I had received from James Noble Senator from Indiana, and John Test, late a member of the House, asking for a postponement of Sales of Land, in a direction where a road is to be laid out, requesting him to examine it, and give directions accordingly— Mr Southard called to read me a Letter from T. Newton of the 16th. at Night. The election for Norfolk County had been held that day— His Election has been bitterly contested by a man misnamed Loyall— But in that County Newton had nearly three votes to one— There are yet the borough and one small County to vote, and Newton is confident of final success. He is one of the fairest and most intelligent men in Congress, as well as the oldest Member of the House of Representatives— Mr Clay came at one O’Clock, and introduced Mr Jackson the late English Commissioner on the joint Commission for Slave indemnities. That Commission being superseded, he is about to return home, and came to take leave in form. His conduct has been far from conciliatory, and he departs without being desired— He expressed however his Gratitude for the kind treatment he had received in the Country— I wished him a prosperous voyage, and a happy return to his native Country— Coll. Jones, the Adjutant General brought me sundry papers from and relating to Lieutt. Alberti who wishes to resign his Commission; the resignation to take effect only at the end of the present year. This Officer has given me much trouble, and is likely to give much more— Mr Nourse, Chief Clerk of the War Department came with some further papers shewing disorders at West-Point— A Quarrel between two of the Officers, and an Order to three of the Cadets to quit the Post— I asked Mr Nourse to send me the last Roll of merit which he did, and told him I should immediately decide upon those cases, having reserved my determination upon each case, until I should have examined them all. Major Harrison, came on a visit with a young man from Philadelphia— Mr Rush called with sundry papers relating to the fruitful subject of E. Thomson’s teas— Sharp complaints from Hone and Haggerty of New-York, and a seeming miscarriage of Instructions given ten days since to R. Tillotson, U.S. District Attorney at that place— Mr Rush concluded to forward a duplicate of his Instructions— He spoke also of some complaint by the Collector at Bristol Rhode-Island, Drury, against an Inspector, appointed by his predecessor Bates. Mr Rush gave me from Dr Mease, a silk ribbon made at New-York— Mr Southard came in while Rush was here, but finding us engaged in business, said he would call again to-morrow morning— Busy evening.
21. IV. Round Capitol Square— Cloudy—

Mr. Graham brought with him maps of the States of Indiana and Ohio, with the Letter from Messrs.Noble and Test, requesting a suspension of the Sales of Lands, on the banks of the Wabash river, where the Canal projected by the State of Indiana will be laid out, and for which a grant of five Sections of Land to the State of Indiana was made by Congress at their last Session— We traced on the maps the course in which the Canal must be directed, from the Wabash to the Miami of the Lake, and I requested Mr Graham to give Instructions at the Land Office to suspend the Sales within the distance from the river which may be occupied by the reservations both for the United States and for the grant to the State— Mr Graham said this Canal would make the shortest passage from New-Orleans to New-York— Mr Nourse brought me a warrant for admission as a Cadet at West-Point for Henry Van Rensselaer, which I enclosed to his father, the Patroon, at Albany, of which John gave notice to J. Blunt of New-York, as he had requested— Mr Southard read me a Letter he had received from John Wurtz, a member of the last Congress from Philadelphia; to whom he had enclosed his Correspondence with General Jackson, about the Conversation at the Fredericksburg dinner. Wurtz’s opinion of the whole affair is correct and candid, and he thinks as I did that Mr Southard ought not to reply to General Jackson’s last Letter to him. Dr Watkins came and introduced a Mr John Davis, from Augusta Maine, who delivered to me several Letters from respectable persons in the State, recommending him for the appointment of Collector at Penobscot— I observed it was too late—the appointment having been already made; a day or two since— He enquired who it was, and upon being informed it was a Mr. Gilman of Hallowell, said it was a very unfortunate appointment; but did not explain himself further— Mr Davis said he had been in the last Presidential Canvas in favour of Mr Crawford; and among the Letters which he brought me was one from William King— R. Forrest brought me to sign, an Exequatur for a person named Delgado, as Mexican Vice-Consul at Boston— Mr Burges called concerning the money which it has been agreed to apply to a Marine Hospital at Providence; for the present 5000 dollars. He thought the Collector of the Port, though a very good Officer, would not superintend the expenditure of the money so advantageously as the Marine Society if it should be placed under their direction. I desired him to see the Secretary of the Treasury upon the Subject, and said I should readily agree to any arrangement of the matter which he should find to be customary, or approve. Mr Burges has been detained here since the close of the Session of Congress, by the illness of two of his daughters— They are however recovering and he proposes going homewards to-morrow— Mr Rush called to introduce his brother James, who is on a visit to him, from Philadelphia— Mary Roberdeau who has been spending some days with Mrs Adams, this Evening went home.
22. V: Sun rose 5:18.

Heard Mr Little, this morning from Psalm 104.14. “He causeth the grass to grow for the cattle, and herb for the service of man: that he may bring forth food, out of the earth; 15. And wine that maketh glad the heart of man, and oil to make his face to shine, and bread, which strengtheneth man’s heart”—and in the Evening from Psalm 65. part of 9 [“]Thou visitest the earth and waterest it— 10. Thou waterest the ridges thereof abundantly: thou settlest the furrow thereof: thou makest it soft with showers: thou blessest the springing thereof”— This was one of Mr Little’s best discourses— Somewhat desultory as his manner is— The general doctrine was to urge the goodness of God, from the annual renovation of Nature in the Spring— There were some pleasing descriptions of the operation of nature upon vegetation, and upon the birds— In the evening Sermon he quoted that most exquisitely affecting description of Spring in the second Chapter of Solomon’s Song—11.12.13—but omitted that which points all
its beauties, the 9th. verse, and the closing clause of the 13th.— He drew also from the phenomena of the physical world in Spring, an argument in favour of a future life; which he weakened however by stating an opinion of some good men that this immortality would be conferred only upon the virtuous; and saying that he gave no opinion upon that point. But this is not Christian doctrine— The language of St Paul is that we must all appear before the judgment Seat of Christ, and there is surely nothing in nature or in revelation to countenance the idea that there is any discrimination of immortality among men— This afternoon, I heard at Mr. Baker’s a Stranger, from Numbers 23.10. “Let me die the death of the righteous, and let my last end by like his!”— The Sermon was sensible and well written though it seemed to me not altogether original; but the voice of the preacher was so extraordinary, that it was unaccountable to me until Mr Baker in the concluding prayer, explained it, by giving an intimation that the preacher was deaf— After the morning service, I called at C. B. King’s the Painter’s, and saw the Portrait he is painting of my Son Charles, which was much improved since I saw it last Sunday— He has also made a very good copy of Stewart’s last Portrait of my father which he borrowed— I omitted writing, after returning from Church this Evening.
23. IV:45. Walk to the Race-ground— Cloudy.— Rainy day.

Mr Nourse came with a Letter, from J. Crowell, Indian Agent with the Creeks, stating that they were going to view the Lands in controversy with the State of Georgia, and of which accession from the Indians has been required— He suggests the expediency that a Letter from the Secretary of War should be written to him declaring the absolute necessity that they should make the cession— I desired Nourse to transmit Crowell’s Letter to Governor Barbour, and inform him of my wish that he would write such a Letter to Crowell— The land is almost worthless—the quantity trifling; and we shall give for it a liberal remuneration— I also desired Mr Nourse to answer Crowell’s Letter immediately and say to him that he would soon receive an Instruction directly from the Secretary of War— Mr Hebb came to say that he had heard the Office of Chief Clerk of the Navy Department, now occupied by Charles Hay, was likely to be soon vacant, and to set forth his wishes and his wants to obtain it— I told him this was an appointment vested by Law, in the head of the Navy Department, and that in the event of the vacancy, he must apply to Mr Southard— Coll. Bomford came again about the spot of land between the Arsenal and the penitentiary, but I had not seen Mr Elgar— Bomford spoke of the great increase of Strength; that Dupont has given to his gunpowder—of the necessary change that it must make in the solidity and weight of the Artillery from which it is discharged; and of the preference of Iron over Brass Cannon; which he says the English and French are but just beginning to discover. Mr Wilson is a member of Congress from Pennsylvania, now here upon business of one of the Collectors of internal Revenue; who has accounts to settle, and a balance against him at the Treasury. He said Mrs Wilson was with him; but they should probably depart to-morrow on their return home— Ironside came for despatches from Mr Gallatin, and other papers belonging to the Department of State that were here. Mr Southard had a Letter from Coll. Smith, of the Marine Corps, at New-York, complaining that there was no decision, upon the Report of the Court of Enquiry in his case— Saying that he could not come to a Settlement with the Suttler’s widow, and declaring his preference of a trial by Court Martial, to the present state of uncertainty in which he was left— I told Mr Southard, he must then call a court martial: though of the most aggravated charge to which Smith was liable, the evidence was probably not clear enough to convict him— Southard had also a Letter from Coll. Washington, a member of Congress elect from Maryland; pressing hard for a Midshipman’s warrant which he had solicited for a friend.— Dunham comes from Belfast, Maine, to apply for an appointment of keeper of a Light-house— He had left several respectable recommendations with Mr Pleasonton, fifth Auditor of the Treasury, and explained to me the reasons upon which he had been confident of success in his application. My Sons John and Charles, dined at Mr Vaughan’s— St. George’s day; now kept in celebration of the king of England’s birth day— Johnson Hellen also dined out.
24. V:15. Round Capitol Square. Cloudy— Showery— Thunder— Clear.

I sent for Mr Elgar to have some conversation with him respecting the partition Wall, to be erected between the Penitentiary and Arsenal grounds; and I desired him to ask Mr Bulfinch to call on me, to take his opinion, upon the same subject. Elgar thought the ground which Bomford asks for, as necessary for the arsenal could not without inconvenience be spared from the Penitentiary; but Bulfinch thought it might— I had no other visitors this day. I am inclining to resume my enquiries, relating to the production and growth of fruit and forest trees. Since I first entered upon them last Summer, a few Books treating of the Subject, have been procured for the Department of State, from London and Paris— I have Loudon’s Encyclopaedia of gardening, fourth Edition 1826. an Octavo Volume of 1240 pages— And his Encyclopaedia of Agriculture, 1825. a similar volume of 1224 pages— And I have this day borrowed from the Department, . . . Treatises of Du Hamel Du Monceau, upon the cultivation of Trees and the uses and treatment of Wood, which have been procured at my request— I find upon consulting them, that there are two others wanted to complete his entire work upon the forests— Looking into these Books I find a wide field opened before me, which I cannot expect that the remnant of life allotted to me, will afford me time to explore: and at present the time that I can bestow upon it is so very little, and cut up with such incessant interruptions, that I fear the result of my pursuit will plunge me into inextricable confusion of mind, without contributing to any useful end— I brought home yesterday from the Race-ground, a twig covered with white blossoms, which upon examination I found to be the Dogwood—Cornus Florida— I had seen it in blossom about a week at the Capitol garden without knowing it— I found the description and Print of it in Michaux’s North-American Sylva. Vol 1. p. 255. and in Bigelow’s Medical Botany. Vol. 2. p. 73— And another Dogwood in Bigelow Vol. 1. p. 93— This morning also, with Antoine I planted four Rows of large Pennsylvania Walnuts— 9. Quincy Walnuts and 3 Hazelnuts in one Row and three Peters Chesnuts, with the rest of the Row in Apple seeds in a different part of the Garden, from that where I planted last November— That bed is now covering itself with weeds; but there was not a symptom of any of my nuts having vegetated— Upon digging however, Antoine found one of the Pennsylvania Walnuts had put forth a shoot which will probably show itself above ground in June—which gives me hopes that others will appear also— The time that I can snatch for this fantastical humour is now the only hour

lg.l: Not wanting power to mitigate and swage
With solemn touches troubled thoughts and chase
Anguish, and doubt, and fear, and sorrow, and pain—

div.p: I wrote a short answer to a Letter from my old friend William Plumer, of Epping, New-Hampshire.
25. V. Sun rose 5:14.— Round Capitol Square.

Mr Lee is composing a Treatise on the cultivation of the vine, and upon wines; and came to ask me to obtain permission for him, to borrow several works upon that subject from the Library of Congress— I wrote to the Librarian accordingly— This is one Branch of the enquiries in which I am engaging but not that to which I can give much attention for the present. Lee promised to send me two or three books on gardening which he now has in use. Mr Graham shewed me a Letter from the Surveyor General Davis, respecting the appointment of a deputy in the place of a Mr Turner, resigned. He mentioned also some collision of Title with regard to a quarter Section of Land, near Tallahassee which had been selected for the grant by Congress to General La Fayette, but which W. P. Duval now Governor of the Territory of Florida, claims to have previously secured to himself.
Obadiah B. Brown, is a Baptist Clergyman, a Clerk in the Post-Office, keeper of a boarding House where Coll. R. M. Johnson the Senator from Kentucky always lodges during the Session of Congress, Director of the Bank of the Metropolis, and principal founder of the Columbian College, now breaking up insolvent. His brother Daniel was a Clerk in the Land Office— One of those whom it recently became necessary to discharge, and to whom the lot fell of going out— After the operation had been performed he wrote me a long memorial, and his brother Obadiah wrote me a Letter complaining of the course pursued by Mr Graham, in not retaining him by preference to others; appealing from this decision and setting forth his distressed condition with a family—and they now called upon me together for my answer— I told them I could not interfere; the appointment of Clerks in the several Departments being vested by Law in their respective heads— That Mr Graham had consulted me as to the manner of executing the Law which required the dismission of several Clerks in the Land Office; and I had approved of his expedient to decide by lot, rather than perform the invidious task of fixing upon the individuals to be discharged— Obadiah thought his brother had a better claim to be retained; but I said there was no jury to decide this, and a brother’s judgment would of course be biassed. Daniel then asked me to return him his Memorial which I did, expressing my regret at the necessity under which he was discharged. Mr Clay came with Knight who is a member of the Senate of Pennsylvania, and is engaged upon the Surveys of the Roads. Mr Rush spoke of the appointment of a judge for the middle District of Florida, in the place of A. B. Woodward, said to be dead or dying; and recommended T. Randall— Also of the appointment of a Collector at Norfolk, and of a Lieutenant to a revenue Cutter. He had a Letter from Mr Berrien of the Senate recommending a Midshipman in the Navy for this appointment. There was a question whether the Commission as Lieutenant could be given him, without his resigning his Warrant as Midshipman. Mr Southard who came in and to whom reference was made said there had been cases of furloughs granted for one or two years to Midshipmen, who then received acting Appointments as Lieutenants in Cutters— Mr Southard came to inform me, of the arrival of Commodore Hull, and the Frigate United States at New-York from the Pacific Ocean— He Offers to Hull the Office of Commissioner of the Navy, from the 1st. of June, when Morris retires from that Station.
26. V. Sun rose 5.13— Round Capitol Square.

Mr Salomon called to enquire, if I had received any recent Letters from Mr. Gallatin, and also to tell me that the Medal I had given him had been received by Mr Sheldon at Paris and would be forwarded by him to Geneva— Doctor Watkins had a paper containing a printed list of persons in many of the States of the Union, named as my friends, and with whom correspondence is invited— It was dated Washington City 5. March 1827. but he received it Post-marked at Cincinnati, and he thought it an indiscreet publication. He also shewed me a Letter from J. Binns at Philadelphia, with a printed Circular— The Letter complains that the Administration does not support its friends, and intimates that sacrifices of time and of money must be made— I have observed the tendency of our electioneering to venality; and shall not encourage it— There is much money expended by the adversaries to the Administration, and it runs chiefly in the channels of the Press— They work by Slander to vitiate the public opinion, and pay for defamation to receive their reward in votes— Coll. Bomford came again upon the subject of the ground in dispute between the Arsenal and the Penitentiary. I told him they might run the road as he had proposed, which Mr Bulfinch thinks may be done without inconvenience to the Penitentiary— Mr Varnum and Mr Knapp called together— Varnum is about departing to return home— Knapp has come back from his visit to his father in New-Hampshire; and has brought his family here to settle in the practice of the Law and as a Journalist. W. Lee came, to speak of books which he had sent me, French and Spanish upon the
culture of the Vine— The Spanish are a Memoir upon the cultivation of the Vine at San Lucar and Xeres, by Don Esteban Boutelou, and an Essay upon the Varieties of the common Vine that grow in Andalusia, by Don Simon de Roxas Clemente y Rubio, both published at Madrid 1807.— The French is the Treatise on the culture of the Vine, by Chaptal, Rozier, Parmentier, and Dussieux—Paris 1801. Lee mentioned also M’Mahon upon gardening; and promised to send it to me— Mr Southard brought me several bundles of papers received from Commodore Hull since his arrival at New-York, and relating to the Transactions of the Squadron under his command in the Pacific— I had been reading numerous papers which he had sent me, concerning the Title of the United States to the Land of the Navy yard at Brooklyn near New-York—part of which is contested— There is an Opinion of the late Chancellor Kent in favour of the Title; but it does not appear to touch the question made by the Claimants— Further enquiries are to be made Mr Clay mentioned the receipt of several despatches from abroad which he afterwards sent me, but which I had not this day time to read— Mrs Adams unwell— I received a cheering Letter from George.
27. IV:45— Sun rose 5:12. Walk to College-Hill.

Mr Davidson was a Teller in the U.S. Branch Bank at this place. There have been considerable frauds practiced at that Office, and charges against the Cashier himself— These have undergone an investigation by two Agents from the Bank at Philadelphia, who have entirely exonerated R. Smith the Cashier from those charges, which were made by the other Teller Weightman, and sustained by the Testimony of Davidson— The Directors of the Board at Philadelphia have required of the Directors of the Branch to dismiss both the Tellers, and to appoint one person to perform the duties of both—giving them at the same time a certificate of entire confidence in their integrity: and allowing them half a year’s Salary on their removal. Davidson brought me these papers, and told me that Dr Watkins had promised to give him a place in his Office, if I would speak a word of recommendation in his favour.— He said he had a wife and nine children, and his brother to maintain and he is himself a cripple, walking upon Crutches— General Macomb called and read me a Letter, from Coll. Little, Member of the House of Representatives in Congress from Baltimore County, urging for the assistance of Engineers in the Surveys to be undertaken in execution of a Railway from Baltimore to the Ohio River. Genl. Macomb said there was one person who could be spared for that purpose, and that similar facilities had been granted to other Undertakings under State authorities heretofore— He said Mr Mercer the Member from Virginia was now in the City, still much occupied with his Chesapeake and Ohio Canal project. These two undertakings rivalise each other and there are strong apprehensions that both will be found impracticable. Mr Bache, the Postmaster at Philadelphia, called upon a visit; returning from an excursion to the South— I spoke to him of his Son Alexander Dallas Bache, who is now an Officer of Engineers, and was graduated two years since with great distinction at West-Point— He is now at Newport with Coll. Totten engaged in the erection of the fortifications at Brenton’s Point— His father said it was in contemplation by some of his friends to have him chosen professor of Mathematics at the University of Philadelphia—to which the only objection was his youth, yet under twenty-one— Mr Southard and Mr Rush were here together— Southard brought me the report made to him by Lieutenant Gregory, upon his return from taking out the Greek Frigate Hope or Hellas, in which he said Gregory complains much of the conduct of the Greek Agent Contostavlos— Mr Rush brought several recommendations for the appointment of a Collector at Norfolk; but the election for Congress is not yet concluded in that District; and T. Newton whose reelection is violently contested, wishes the appointment not to be made till that is over
28. IV:45. Rain. Walk to Potowmack River rock.
