Mr Clay came with a Letter from Mr Noble the Senator, and Mr Test late Member of the House, complaining that they were informed the Commissioners of the General Land-Office had determined that no Surveys of Public Lands in the State of Indiana, could be made before the next Session of Congress, because no specific appropriation for it was made for it at the last Session— They insist that there was an appropriation which although not specific was intended for that object— I received also a Letter from them of the same purport— Mr Clay had also a Letter from Enoch Lincoln, Governor of the State of Maine; upon the question of the boundary of that State now in negotiation with Great Britain— Its temper is querulous testy, and suspicious— He insists upon a demand for copies of all the documents relating to the Negotiation comments censoriously upon passages of Mr Gallatin’s despatches which have been communicated to him, denies the right of the General Government to cede any part of a Sovereign and Independent State; and dwells much upon the right of the State to call upon the general Government for protection—protesting at the same time against any compromise at the expense of the State— The tendency of all this is to multiply the difficulties of the Negotiation, and promises no good to the State: but if the State Government were much better humoured, and even disposed to a compromise of the question, there is little prospect that it could now be settled upon reasonable terms— Mr Sullivan, son of William Sullivan of Boston brought me a Letter of Introduction from D. Webster— He is upon an excursion to Virginia— Wyer has just returned from Point Comfort where he went to bring up a Son of Mr Pleasonton’s, ill with a bilious fever. He has also been at Richmond and saw Stevenson there— Mr Southard came to introduce Mr Piper a visitor from Chester, Pennsylvania— The remains of my Catarrhal cold are yet hanging about me— Johnson Hellen absent
29. V:10. Cloudy— Rain— First Potowmack bath, this Season—

Heard at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read prayers for the second Sunday after Easter, and Mr Henry Van Dyke Johns, of Frederick, preached from Isaiah 45.22. “Look unto me, and be ye saved, all the ends of the earth: for I am God, and none else.” His language and delivery are good— His Doctrines minatory, and trinitarian, his manner earnest and vehement, and his whole discourse declamatory— Notice was given of a Sunday School meeting this afternoon at Mr Post’s Church, which supersedes the usual meetings at the Churches of which the Union is composed— Mr Myers of Norfolk called to visit me, and remembered having first seen me at Amsterdam in 1783—and also having been a fellow traveller with me in September 1801. from New-York to Boston— He also called upon me two or three times while I was in the Department of State— He is now on his return to Norfolk from Philadelphia— In the Evening I heard Mr Little, from Romans 1:20. “For the invisible things of him from the creation of the world, are clearly seen, being understood by the things that are made, even his eternal power and Godhead: so that they are without excuse”— The argument of St. Paul in this Chapter is that the existence and Nature of God, are inferrable from the visible Creation—that the heathens, by rejecting this evidence, and by their vain imaginations, substituted corruptible man, birds, beasts or reptiles, instead of the true God, were without excuse—and that this fantastic preference of idolatry to the worship of the true God, was the source of all loose, depraved and vicious morals— The connection between the belief of one omnipotent Spirit, creator of the visible universe, and pure morality, is here stated with great force—and that of depraved morals, with idolatry— St. Paul says that God gave them up to vile affections, and a reprobate mind, because they refused to acknowledge him— These positions seem to deserve full and particular illustration; but Mr Little confined himself to a single view of the Subject, the unreasonableness and absurdity of Atheism— Now St. Paul is not here censuring Atheism, but Polytheism—not the disbelief of any God, but the perverted belief of human and brutal Gods— And he is shewing the necessary connection between such perverted belief and all the vices of unnatural lust, of cruelty and of fraud. A philosophical developement of the secondary causes by which these effects are operated would be acceptable, and instructive to me.
30. V:10. Sun risen at 5.8. Behind Chimney State Department— Walk to the College—

Mr Graham came with a Letter from Mr Hendricks one of the Senators from Indiana, complaining of the order to the Surveyor General, to supersede all Surveys in that State, because no specific appropriation was made for them at the last Session of Congress— There was indeed an appropriation generally for surveys, of twenty thousand dollars, but it was made upon estimates not including these Surveys and before the Indian Treaty by which the lands were acquired had been ratified. The omission to make a subsequent additional appropriation was an oversight, which the Indiana members now feel will be imputable specially to them; and hence their great anxiety upon the subject— Mr Graham however observed that a part of the appropriation actually made might be applied to the Indiana surveys, at the hazard at having the fund fall short, for those on the estimate of which it was given, and perhaps some might be made in the anticipated confidence of an appropriation at the next Session of Congress, and I agreed that he should instruct the Surveyor General accordingly. Mr Rush came with a petition from Boston, for the remission of a forfeiture, of a British vessel from Bermuda; which has entered the Port, since the Proclamation of 17. March was issued. This vessel was chartered at Bermuda, to bring home the Cargo, of an American vessel which had entered there in distress— Sailed from Bermuda 7. of this month, before the existence of the Proclamation was known there; and the property belongs to a Citizen of the United States— I agreed with Mr Rush that this was a case for the remission of the forfeiture— Dr. Lovell came and introduced a brother of General Brown’s, and another person perhaps an officer in the army, but whose name I did not ascertain— And Mr Clay introduced Mr Beale, a visitor from Kentucky— Mr Southard had a Letter from Captain Ridgely, who had been with the frigate Constellation to La Guayra, and communicated with the Consul, Williamson, but did not go into the Harbour. He had also a Letter from Captain Jones of the Sloop of War, Lexington, at St. Blas, on the Pacific Ocean— She had been to the Sandwich Islands, and Jones gives a bad account of Percival, who had preceded him there in the Dolphin— Percival is in prison at New-York, upon suits at Law, brought against him by Alfred P. Edwards and others. I was employed much of this day in preparing decisions upon the trials of nineteen Cadets at West-Point—eleven of whom the Court Martial have sentenced to be dismissed— In the examination of these cases several questions of importance have occurred to me requiring much reflection, and upon which I have not been able to come to a satisfactory conclusion. These difficulties have delayed my decision upon the trials, for several weeks. Miss Mary Roberdeau came again to pass some days with us.

Day. The average of my rising hour through the month has been five, immediately after which, I take a walk of an hour and a quarter— I then read an hour, and write an hour, and often waste an hour upon some trifle of idleness— At nine we breakfast, which with the Morning Newspaper soaks up from one to two hours and thence till five in the afternoon, I am engaged with the Mails from South and North, the Heads of Departments, with business, and voluminous papers, and visitors, Strangers, Petitioners, and Officers, so that I can never apply with certainty a quarter of an hour together to any one pursuit. At five we dine, and I take two hours or more of leisure and relaxation— From seven till ten or eleven I apply to the arrears of my Diary Index, and to writing upon the Colonial trade question. Then retire for the Night. This life is regular and very little varied— My health has been the whole month bad— My anticipations for the two succeeding years, calls for more than Stoic fortitude. As life draws towards its close, it loses value philosophically every day, but physically becomes more precious— For all that is past Gratitude is the only sentiment that should fill my Soul, as the future should be allotted to humble hope, to firm reliance, and to resignation.
